body.paragraph: Salvation by works is a doctrine taught in the early Roman Catholic Church—as well as Eastern Orthadox churches, Latter-day Saints (Mormons), and Jehovah's Witnesses—which stated that good works contributes to a person's salvation, and that faith in the sacrifice of Jesus is not soley sufficient to save one from Hell.

This doctrine was challenged during the Protestant Reformation, particularly by Martin Luther, who emphasized justification by faith alone (sola fide), citing Ephesians 2:8-9. The Reformers argued that salvation is a gift of God's grace, received through faith, and not earned by human efforts or works.
Most modern churches affirm salvation by grace through faith (sola fide), while recognizing that good works are a natural outcome (often coined "fruit") of genuine faith.
